Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving the Effectiveness of Practice Exams in Large Introductory Physics Courses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving students' success in introductory STEM courses. For many college and university students, "gateway" courses, such as introductory physics, present a roadblock to further study in STEM fields. Every semester approximately 4,000 students take introductory courses in the Department of Physics at the University of Illinois. Most of the students are engineering majors, because physics is a required course for all programs in the College of Engineering. Despite instructors' use of evidence-based instructional methods such as online pre-lectures, active-learning lectures, "just-in-time teaching," peer instruction, and collaborative problem-solving in recitation sections, nearly 15 percent of students do not pass the introductory courses. Most of these failing students actively participate in class and exert substantial effort, but nevertheless receive low grades on exams. When surveyed about the resources that they find most helpful in learning the material, students cite practice exams with video solutions as the highest-rated component of the course. Although considerable research shows that practice exams can be an effective form of studying, the degree of effectiveness depends on how the students engage with the exams. Indeed, simply reviewing problems and solutions develops familiarity with the material to be tested, but it does not often support the needed problem-solving ability. Consequently, lower-performing students become overconfident in their problem-solving ability and believe they are prepared to do well on exams, but instead they receive failing grades. This project will investigate whether changing the format of students' interactions with the practice exams, to encourage earlier use and to provide a more accurate assessment of understanding, will result in more effective studying behavior. If so, it may enable students to make a better self-assessment of their readiness and increase performance on exams.

This project aims to advance knowledge in three areas that are critical for improving the effectiveness of practice exams as a learning resource, especially for underperforming students. First, it will explore students' difficulty in assessing their level of understanding, also known as the Dunning Kroeger effect, in STEM gateway courses. Although this effect has been verified in a variety of situations, the investigators will not only measure the size of the effect but also develop insights about whether improving students' ability to assess their level of understanding improves their performance (i.e., Is the correlation causal?). Second, the project will explore the role that implementation has on how students interact with practice exams and their effectiveness in helping students learn. In particular, the investigators will attempt to measure the impact that providing students a more realistic score on their practice exam has on the accuracy of their own understanding of how well they know the material. Third, the project will explore the impact that encouraging distributed practice can have on student performance, as well as the effectiveness of a relatively simple approach to encouraging that practice. In addition to guiding future education research, the knowledge gained from this project should maximize the effectiveness of practice exams for the at-risk students who need them most. At the University of Illinois alone, the results of the research should improve learning for thousands of students every year who hope to become engineers. However, the results should transfer to introductory physics courses at other institutions and introductory courses in other disciplines, thus magnifying the potential impact of this work. This collaborative project involves investigators at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (Award DUE-2021099) and Purdue University (Award DUE-2021190). This project is funded by the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE: EHR) program, which supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

The Department of Physics at the University of Illinois teaches approximately 4000 undergraduate students every semester. Despite using evidence-based instructional methods such as online prelectures, active learning lectures, just-in-time teaching, peer instruction, and collaborative problem-solving in recitation sections, nearly 15% of students do not pass the introductory courses. This corresponds to approximately 500 students every year. Most of these failing students actively participate in class and exert substantial effort but receive low exam grades. When surveyed about the resources students found most helpful in learning the material, practice exams with video solutions were the highest-rated component of the course (see Figure 1). Although there is considerable research showing practice exams can be an effective form of studying, the effectiveness depends on how the students engage with the exams. Indeed, simply looking at the problems and reviewing the solutions facilitate familiarity with the material to be tested but do not often support problem-solving ability. This results in lower-performing students becoming overconfident in their problem-solving abilities. As a result, they believe that they are prepared to do well on exams but instead receive failing grades.  In this proposal, we investigated how changing the format of the student interactions with the practice exams to encourage earlier use and provide a more accurate assessment of their understanding impacted their studying behavior, metacognitive monitoring, and exam performance.

Project Outcomes:

The project's first phase involved changing the format, so students needed to submit their answers before they could see the help video, and their practice exam score reflected their first attempt, even if they later corrected the answer.  This score based on students' first attempt more accurately reflected their preparedness for the exam.  However, student surveys revealed that even with this more accurate evaluation, they were not more accurate at predicting their preparedness for the exam!  Indeed, underprepared students showed a remarkable ability to disregard their low practice exam scores when asked to predict how they would perform on the actual exam.  Figure 2 shows how students who were less prepared for the exam vastly overestimated how much better they would perform on the actual exam than they did. This result illustrates the robustness of the Dunning-Kroeger effect and the difficulty people have in assessing their level of understanding. 

Results from the first phase of this project demonstrated that students did not change their studying even when they had clear evidence from their practice exams that they were not prepared for the upcoming exam.  Indeed, they seemed to simply ignore the data provided by the practice exams. To better understand what could change student study strategies, and which changes were effective, we collected data to correlate any changes they make in their studying based on their satisfaction with their actual exam score.  Furthermore, we looked at how these changes impacted their performance on future exams.  The results were quite interesting.  While many students mentioned working harder or doing more practice problems, those changes had mixed impacts on their future performance. The students who showed the most significant performance improvement described engaging more deeply with the material.  Often, this took the form of participating more in group problem-solving during their discussion sections and being more willing to ask questions when they were confused.   Although we had hoped that improving the quality of the formative assessment in the practice exams would provide large improvements for struggling students, it makes sense that these students require a more sustained and significant intervention.  These results clearly indicate the importance of getting these students to engage more deeply with the content earlier in the process.  Indeed, the results from this experiment have inspired us to restructure the recitation section activities to help facilitate that deeper engagement.

Broader Impact:

Results from this project illuminate the most effective strategy for achieving our goal of making a STEM career a viable option for a broader segment of our society. Succeeding in gateway courses, such as introductory physics, is a roadblock for many students. Based on our results, we will restructure the recitation sections to encourage deeper engagement and great student interactions. At the University of Illinois alone, this will impact thousands of students who are hoping to become engineers every year. However, the impact will be much larger since the knowledge gained from this research is transferable to the introductory/gateway courses in STEM.

 

This project resulted in 3 refereed publications and four presentations at national conferences. It also partially supported the research of three graduate students' PhD thesis.
